Details.Description: This file includes the persona of an individual interviewed using the Jobs-to-be-Done (JTBD) framework for a new product. It also contains the full transcript of the qualitative interview, documenting the conversation between the interviewer and the individual.

persona.name: Kimberly Smith
persona.background_story: Kimberly grew up in a middle-class neighborhood in Seattle. Her mother was a nurse, and her father was an electrician. From a young age, Kimberly was inspired by her mother's compassion and dedication to helping others. Despite financial challenges, she was determined to pursue a career in nursing, which she saw as a path to making a meaningful impact in people's lives. She attended the University of Washington, where she excelled academically and developed a strong sense of empathy and resilience. Kimberly values family, health, and professional excellence, which guide her in her personal and professional life.

psychographics.values_and_beliefs: Kimberly holds core values such as honesty, compassion, and dedication to family and community. She believes in continuous learning and the importance of work-life balance.

behavioral_traits.emotional_resilience: Kimberly handles stress well, often using her support network and practices like yoga to recover from setbacks.

emotional_triggers.positive_triggers: Feeling appreciated and seeing positive outcomes from her work make her feel valued.
emotional_triggers.negative_triggers: Being undervalued or encountering inefficiency makes her feel frustrated.

motivations.intrinsic_motivations: Passion for helping others and personal growth

challenges.personal_challenges: Maintaining work-life balance and managing stress
challenges.professional_challenges: Keeping up with industry trends and learning new skills
challenges.communication_challenges: Sometimes struggles with articulation during emotional situations

life_outside_work.social_circle: Has a tight-knit social group of colleagues and childhood friends

family_life.importance_of_family: Family is central to her identity and a major motivator in her life.
family_life.family_role: Kimberly is a caregiver and supporter within her family.

life_outside_work.community_involvement: Kimberly volunteers at local health fairs and participates in neighborhood events.

professional_goals.short_term_goals: Earn a certification in advanced cardiac life support
professional_goals.long_term_goals: Achieve work-life balance and potentially move into nursing management

frustrations_pain_points.professional_frustrations: Bureaucratic delays and lack of recognition in the workplace
frustrations_pain_points.communication_frustrations: Feeling misunderstood or not listened to in meetings

daily_tasks.personal_routine: Commutes by car, exercises with yoga, and spends evenings with family
daily_tasks.work_routine: Starts with checking patient records, attending rounds, and managing patient care

cognitive_biases.optimism_bias: Tends to be confident in personal career decisions
cognitive_biases.confirmation_bias: Prefers information that supports her belief in the importance of holistic patient care
cognitive_biases.anchoring_bias: Relies on past successful experiences to make current decisions
cognitive_biases.availability_bias: Recalls successful patient stories when assessing new situations

response_to_interview_context.adaptability_during_interviews: Adjusts well to unexpected questions, displaying confidence and composure

customer_journey.awareness_stage: Becomes aware through professional networks and online communities
customer_journey.consideration_stage: Considers recommendations, quality, and price when making decisions
customer_journey.decision_stage: Relies on quality and peer recommendations to make decisions
customer_journey.post_purchase_behavior: Loyal to brands that align with her values and offer consistent quality

transcript.text: Hello! Thank you for joining me today. I'm really looking forward to our conversation. To start, could you tell me a little bit about your current job and what your typical workday looks like?

Hi there! I'm a registered nurse, and I work in Seattle. My typical workday kicks off with checking patient records to get the lay of the land for the day. I spend a lot of time managing patient care, attending rounds, and coordinating with doctors and the rest of the healthcare team. It's a dynamic and sometimes hectic environment, but I love being able to help people and make a difference in their lives. Every day brings something new, which keeps me on my toes!

That sounds both challenging and rewarding. It's clear that your role involves a lot of movement and activity. Can you describe a typical day at work in more detail and how it affects your footwear choices?

Absolutely! Since I'm on my feet for most of my shift, comfort in footwear is a must. My day involves a lot of walking back and forth between patient rooms, sometimes in a hurry, and occasionally standing in one spot for a while during procedures or consultations. I always look for shoes that offer good support and cushioning to prevent fatigue, and ones that are easy to clean since workplaces can get, well, messy sometimes. Sneakers or clogs designed for healthcare professionals are usually my go-to choices.
I see. It seems that comfort and functionality are really important for you. Could you elaborate more on how your feet typically feel at the end of your shift?

By the end of a shift, my feet can feel pretty tired, especially if it's been a particularly busy day. There can be some soreness, mainly if I've been on my feet more than usual. Good shoes help a lot, but I still make sure to stretch and sometimes use a foot roller when I get home to ease any tension. Taking care of my feet is key to being ready for the next day!

That makes a lot of sense. It sounds like you have a solid routine for taking care of your feet. Can you recall a specific moment when you realized you needed to change your footwear? What prompted that decision?

Oh, definitely! I remember one particularly long shift where I was dealing with some back-to-back emergencies, and by the end of the day, my feet were killing me. They hurt so much that I was limping a bit on the way to my car. That night, I decided it was time to invest in a better pair of shoes. I did some research and opted for a pair specifically designed for healthcare professionals. It was like night and day once I made the switch, and I haven’t looked back since!
That sounds like a significant turning point. What were the specific features you looked for in those new shoes that made such a difference for you?

I was really focused on finding shoes with excellent arch support and cushioning, which would help ease the pressure on my feet during long hours. I also looked for shoes with good traction to prevent slipping, especially since hospital floors can be quite slick. Breathability was another factor, to keep my feet dry and comfortable throughout the day. Lastly, they had to be easy to clean, given the nature of the job. Those specific features made a huge difference in my comfort and how my feet felt at the end of each day.

Thank you for sharing those details. It’s clear that those features are crucial for you. Have you ever experienced foot pain or discomfort despite having what you considered a good pair of shoes? If so, can you elaborate on that experience?

Yeah, there have been times when I've experienced foot pain even with decent shoes. It's usually during particularly hectic weeks when I'm clocking in more hours than usual or if I'm not paying attention to my posture or gait. Even the best shoes can only do so much if I'm overworking or not taking enough breaks to stretch and rest. After those weeks, I make a conscious effort to do better self-care and make sure I’m rotating my shoes to keep them in good shape.
It sounds like balancing self-care with the demands of your job is quite important. Switching gears a bit, how does the style of your shoes affect your confidence at work?

Style definitely plays a role in how I feel at work. While comfort is the top priority, I do appreciate having shoes that look good too. If they match my scrubs or add a bit of personal flair, it makes me feel more put-together and confident. It's a small thing, but feeling good about how I look can boost my mood and confidence, which is always helpful in a high-pressure environment like healthcare.
That's interesting to hear. Can you describe how your colleagues influence your choice of footwear?

My colleagues definitely have some influence! We're always sharing recommendations and tips on shoes that have worked well for us. If I see someone with a stylish or particularly functional pair, I'll often ask for their feedback. We all understand the demands of the job and are usually on the lookout for anything that can help make our shifts easier on our feet. So, their experiences and suggestions can play a big role in what I consider when buying new shoes.
It sounds like you have a supportive network when it comes to finding the right footwear. How important is it for you that your shoes reflect your personal style?

While function is key, it's nice to have shoes that reflect a bit of my personal style. I tend to go for designs that are simple but with a pop of color or a unique detail that makes them feel like me. It's a small way to express my personality, even if most of what I'm wearing is pretty standardized with scrubs. Plus, it just adds a bit more joy to the daily routine, which is always a plus!
I can see how those touches of personal style can make a big difference in your day. Have you ever received compliments or comments on your work shoes? How did that make you feel?

Yes, I have! It's always nice to hear compliments from colleagues about my shoes, especially if they're noticing the details I liked when choosing them. It makes me feel like my choices resonate with the people around me and gives me a little sense of pride in my taste and practicality. It’s like a little boost to the day when someone notices something that might seem minor but is actually pretty important when you're in them all day!
I imagine that kind of positive feedback can be quite uplifting. Do you feel any pressure to conform to certain styles or brands in your work environment?

Not really. In my work environment, there's less focus on brands or styles and more emphasis on comfort and functionality. We’re all just looking for what helps us get through our shifts comfortably and safely. There's an understanding among us that everyone has their preferences, and it's more about what works for each individual rather than sticking to a specific brand or style.
It's great to hear that you have that level of understanding and flexibility. Now, moving on to functional aspects, what are the most important functional features you look for in your work shoes?

The most important functional features for me are definitely arch support and cushioning, as they provide comfort during long shifts. Good grip is also essential to avoid any slipping accidents, given the hospital floors can be smooth and sometimes wet. Breathability is another big factor, so my feet stay dry. Lastly, durability is key because they need to stand up to a lot of wear and tear over time. These features really help in keeping my feet happy throughout the week!
It sounds like you have a well-rounded set of criteria. How do you assess the durability of a shoe before purchasing it?

When assessing a shoe's durability, I usually look at the materials used—leather or reinforced mesh tend to hold up well. I'll also check reviews from others in the healthcare field to see how long the shoes typically last for them. Physically, I'll examine the construction—things like sturdy stitching and a solid sole indicate good durability. If I can try them on, I'll see how they feel structurally, like checking if they provide good support and don't feel flimsy. All these factors together give me a pretty good sense of how well a shoe will last.
It's clear you put a lot of thought into evaluating durability. Can you describe a situation where a shoe did not live up to your expectations in terms of support or comfort?

Sure thing. There was a pair I bought because they looked stylish and had decent reviews, but when it came to long shifts, they just didn’t provide enough arch support. My feet started to ache halfway through the day, and I realized they weren’t built for the kind of hours I put in. It was disappointing to have to cut my losses, but it taught me to prioritize support over appearance, especially for work shoes. After that experience, I focused more on trying out shoes in-store whenever possible to really feel the support before buying.
That sounds like a valuable lesson learned, albeit a frustrating one. What role does the brand play in your decision to purchase a particular shoe?

The brand does play a role, but it's not the most important factor for me. I tend to stick with brands that have a good reputation for quality and comfort, particularly ones known for making shoes for healthcare professionals. If I've had a positive experience with a brand before, I'm more likely to trust their products again. That said, I'm always open to trying something new if it seems to meet my needs and has good reviews from people in similar roles.
It’s good to hear you’re open to exploring new options while valuing trusted brands. Moving on to the next aspect, how often do you replace your work shoes, and what factors influence that decision?

I typically replace my work shoes every 6 to 12 months. The timing can depend on how much wear and tear they’ve endured and how they’re holding up in terms of support and comfort. If I start noticing that my feet are getting sore more quickly, or if I see visible signs of wear like worn-out soles or compromised support, that's my cue to start looking for a replacement. Keeping my feet healthy is a top priority, so I try not to wait too long when it's clear the shoes are past their prime.
That makes a lot of sense, ensuring you're always comfortable and supported. How do different working conditions, like long shifts or the hospital setting, affect your footwear needs?

Working long shifts and being in a hospital setting definitely heighten the need for comfort, durability, and safety in footwear. Long shifts mean I'm on my feet for hours, so I need shoes that provide consistent support and cushioning to avoid fatigue. The hospital environment can also be unpredictable, with potential spills or slick floors, so good traction is a must to prevent accidents. Additionally, shoes that are easy to clean are critical, given the medical setting. All these factors mean my footwear needs to be reliable and able to handle whatever the day throws at me.
It's clear that your work environment demands a lot from your footwear. Can you tell me about a time when you had to adapt your footwear choice due to a change in your work situation?

Sure! There was a time when I was temporarily moved to a different wing of the hospital, which involved a lot more walking than I was used to. My usual shoes were fine for my regular unit, but with the increased distance, I found they weren't as comfortable by the end of the day. I switched to a pair with better cushioning and support to handle the extra walking, and it made a significant difference. Adapting to that change reminded me how crucial it is to have shoes that can meet the specific needs of your environment.
That sounds like it was an important adjustment for you. How do seasonal changes impact your shoe preferences?

Seasonal changes can definitely impact my shoe preferences. In the winter, I might look for shoes with a bit more insulation to keep my feet warm, and I'll make sure they have a good grip for navigating icy parking lots. During the warmer months, breathability becomes even more important because I want to keep my feet as cool and dry as possible. While my main work shoes remain consistent in terms of support and comfort, these seasonal considerations help ensure I’m comfortable year-round.

It's great to see how you adjust your footwear to match seasonal needs. Speaking of adjustments, how do you balance the need for a professional appearance with comfort and functionality in your shoe choices?

Balancing a professional appearance with comfort and functionality is all about finding the right compromise. I typically choose shoes that have a clean, simple design that complements my scrubs. Brands that specialize in healthcare footwear often offer options that look professional while still providing the necessary support and comfort. I focus on neutral colors or subtle patterns that add a bit of personality while maintaining a tidy appearance. This way, I can feel confident and comfortable throughout my shift without sacrificing one for the other.

That makes a lot of sense, finding that balance to match both needs. Are there any specific policies or guidelines regarding footwear at your workplace? If so, how do they impact your purchasing decisions?

Yes, there are some general guidelines at my workplace that dictate footwear needs to be closed-toe and have non-slip soles for safety reasons. These policies ensure that everyone maintains a certain level of safety and hygiene. When purchasing shoes, I make sure they're compliant with these guidelines, which helps narrow down my options. Because the requirements align with priorities I already have—like safety and practicality—the policies don't feel restrictive. They actually help me focus on the features that really matter for my role.

It sounds like the guidelines are quite practical and align well with your priorities. Now, considering decision-making, can you describe the process you go through when deciding to purchase new shoes for work?

When I decide it's time to purchase new work shoes, I start by assessing what didn't work with my current pair and what features I need to prioritize. Then, I usually read reviews or ask colleagues for recommendations, especially if I'm considering a new brand or model. Trying them on in-store is ideal so I can feel the fit and support firsthand, but if I buy online, I make sure there's a good return policy. I look for features that match the hospital guidelines and my personal needs—like arch support, non-slip soles, and durability. Once I’ve weighed all these factors, I make the purchase, trusting my choice will handle the demands of my job.
It's a thorough decision-making process. What are the primary factors that trigger you to buy new footwear?

The primary factors that trigger me to buy new footwear are usually discomfort or a noticeable decline in support and cushioning in my current shoes. Visible signs of wear, like worn-out soles or the shoes feeling less sturdy, are also big indicators. Sometimes, if I start experiencing more foot fatigue than usual at the end of my shifts, that's a clear sign it’s time for an upgrade. Essentially, anything that affects my comfort or safety while working can prompt me to start looking for a new pair.
It’s clear that your comfort and safety are the major triggers for purchasing new shoes. How do reviews or recommendations influence your purchasing decisions?

Reviews and recommendations play a big role in my purchasing decisions. I really value firsthand accounts from others in similar roles, as they provide insights into how the shoes perform in a healthcare setting. Positive reviews about comfort, durability, and specific features like support can sway me towards trying a particular pair. Recommendations from colleagues are especially influential since I trust their experiences and can see how the shoes hold up in real-time. While I still consider my personal preferences and needs, these insights are incredibly helpful in guiding my choices.
It's clear that reviews and peer recommendations are significant for you. Can you recall a time when a promotional offer swayed your decision to buy a particular brand or style?

Honestly, while I appreciate a good deal, a promotional offer alone usually isn't enough to sway my decision when it comes to work shoes. Comfort and functionality are too important to compromise on, so I focus on those factors first. That said, if there's a promotion on a shoe that checks all my boxes in terms of needs and has good reviews, it can definitely make the purchase feel more satisfying. But the core decision is always based on how well the shoes meet my work demands.
That’s a wise approach, prioritizing functionality over promotions. Are there any specific attributes or features that instantly attract you to a shoe?

Definitely! Features that instantly attract me are good arch support and cushioning because they’re crucial for long shifts. I'm also drawn to shoes with a non-slip sole for safety and those that are easy to clean, given the hospital environment. Breathability is another key feature since no one wants sweaty feet during a long day. If a shoe combines these features with a clean, professional look, it catches my attention right away.
It's clear that specific functional features are top priorities for you. What frustrates you most about your current work shoes?

The most frustrating thing about my current work shoes is that after using them for a while, they gradually start losing their cushioning and support. Even though they’re made for long hours, the wear and tear of daily use eventually starts to show. Sometimes they can also be a bit too warm during long shifts, which isn’t ideal. These issues serve as reminders to keep an eye out for replacements when the time comes.
That does sound frustrating, especially given how important comfort and support are. Can you describe a past experience where a shoe let you down, and what you did about it?

Sure! I once had a pair of shoes that seemed comfortable at first but started giving me blisters after a few intense shifts. It was frustrating because everything else about them seemed fine initially. I tried using different socks to alleviate the issue and even added gel inserts, but nothing worked consistently. Eventually, I had to accept that they just weren't a good fit for my feet or the demands of my job. I ended up replacing them with a different pair that had better arch support and a wider fit, which solved the problem. It was a lesson in the importance of breaking in shoes properly and ensuring they fit well before diving into long shifts.
It sounds like that experience taught you a lot about what to look for in a work shoe. How do you cope with discomfort or foot pain during your shifts?

When I experience discomfort or foot pain during shifts, I try to take short breaks when possible to rest and stretch my feet. I also keep some cushioned insoles handy, which can offer a bit more comfort in the meantime. Once my shift is over, soaking my feet in warm water or using a foot roller helps relieve any lingering tension. Staying proactive with these little habits helps me cope better and keeps the discomfort from becoming a bigger issue.
It's great to hear you have strategies in place to manage discomfort. Are there any brands or styles you avoid due to past negative experiences?

I generally avoid brands or styles that have previously lacked the necessary support or cushioning for long hours on my feet. If a certain shoe has given me blisters or didn’t hold up well over time, I’ll steer clear of similar designs in the future. I’ve learned to be cautious with shoes that are too fashion-focused and might sacrifice comfort for style. Once bitten, twice shy, as they say!
It’s wise to learn from past experiences. What improvements would you like to see in the design of shoes intended for nurses?

I’d love to see improvements in durability without sacrificing comfort, so they last longer under the stress of long shifts. Enhanced breathability while maintaining support would also be fantastic, especially for the warmer months. If there could be more options that combine style with the required functionality, like non-slip soles and easy-to-clean materials, that would be great too. Shoes that maintain their support and cushioning longer would make a huge difference in daily comfort and overall foot health.
It sounds like those improvements would really enhance your work experience. Have you recently switched brands or styles? If so, what prompted the change?

I haven’t switched brands recently, but I’m always on the lookout for options that might better meet my needs. If I were to switch, it would likely be prompted by a colleague’s recommendation or if I found a shoe that promised better support and longevity than what I'm currently wearing. I’m open to trying new things as long as they align with what I know works for me in terms of comfort and safety.
It's great to stay open to new possibilities while knowing what works best for you. What attributes would an ideal work shoe for nurses have, in your opinion?

An ideal work shoe for nurses would have excellent arch support and cushioning to keep feet comfortable during long shifts. It would need a non-slip sole for safety on the hospital floors and be made from breathable, easy-to-clean materials. Durability is key, so they should maintain their structure and support over time. A good range of sizes with options for different foot widths would help ensure a proper fit. Lastly, a touch of style or personalization options wouldn't hurt to let us express a bit of our personality while maintaining that professional look.
Those attributes sound like they would cover all the essential needs effectively. How open are you to trying new brands or styles, and what factors would encourage you to make a change?

I'm definitely open to trying new brands or styles if they seem to offer better support or features than what I currently have. Key factors that would encourage me to make a change include positive reviews from peers, recommendations from colleagues, and if the shoes have specific features that address issues I've faced in the past, like better durability or improved breathability. Also, if I find a pair that meets my needs and comes with a good return policy, I’d be more willing to give them a try.
It's great to see you're open to new options with solid criteria to guide your choices. Can you describe a situation where you were hesitant to try a new shoe, but ended up satisfied with the change?

Certainly! There was a time I was hesitant to try a new brand recommended by a colleague because it was slightly pricier than what I usually went for. I wasn't sure if the investment would actually pay off. However, after hearing multiple positive reviews about their comfort and durability from other nurses, I decided to give them a shot. Once I started using them, I immediately noticed a difference in comfort, especially during longer shifts. The extra support was worth the initial hesitation, and I'm glad I made the switch. It taught me that sometimes it's worth taking a chance on something new, especially with solid recommendations.
It's wonderful to hear the change turned out well for you. What would make you loyal to a particular shoe brand or style?

Loyalty to a particular shoe brand or style comes down to consistently delivering comfort, support, and durability. If a brand repeatedly provides shoes that meet these needs and keep me comfortable through my shifts, that earns my trust. Consistent quality, paired with options that accommodate my style preferences and a good customer service experience, would solidify my loyalty. Also, if they listen to feedback and continually improve their products based on user input, that's a big plus in maintaining my trust and ensuring I'll continue choosing their shoes.

That makes a lot of sense. Brands that deliver consistent quality and listen to customer feedback can certainly earn loyalty. Based on your experiences, what advice would you give to a shoe designer creating footwear for nurses?

I’d advise a shoe designer to focus on the core needs of nurses: comfort, support, durability, and safety. Creating shoes with excellent arch support and cushioning is crucial for those long hours on our feet. Non-slip soles are essential for safety, given the hospital environment. Prioritize materials that are breathable and easy to clean, ensuring they can handle the demands of the job. Additionally, offering a range of sizes and widths for a better fit would be very appreciated. Finally, combining these functional needs with a touch of style or personalization options can make the shoes appealing, allowing nurses to express a bit of their personality while feeling professional.
Those recommendations are insightful and clearly based on your extensive experience. Are there any other factors or experiences you would like to share regarding your footwear preferences?

I think we've covered most of the main factors, but I’d add that it’s really important to give shoes a proper break-in period. Even shoes with all the right features can feel uncomfortable at first, so I try to gradually wear them for shorter shifts before jumping into a long day. Also, rotating between a couple of pairs can really help extend their lifespan and comfort over time. Lastly, as much as we focus on shoes, taking care of our feet with regular stretches and rest is just as important to balance out the demands of the job.

Those are excellent additional points, especially about breaking in shoes and foot care. How do you envision the future of work shoes for nurses, and what role do you see yourself playing in that evolution?

I envision the future of work shoes for nurses focusing on integrating advanced materials and technologies that enhance comfort and support while remaining lightweight and durable. Innovations like custom-fit options through 3D scanning or sustainable materials could be game-changers. I see myself contributing to this evolution by continuing to provide feedback and actively participating in discussions or studies that test new product developments. Being open to trying new innovations and sharing my experiences can help designers create shoes that meet our needs even better. Plus, collaborating with peers to express what truly works for us can push the industry towards more targeted and effective solutions.

Your vision for the future is quite forward-thinking and practical. Your contributions and feedback would certainly be valuable in shaping those advancements. Is there anything else you would like to add that we haven't covered?

I think we’ve covered everything quite thoroughly! I’d just emphasize the importance of listening to those who wear the shoes day in and day out—our feedback is essential for continuous improvement. Finding the right pair truly makes a difference not just in comfort, but in the overall ability to perform well and stay focused in a demanding job. Thank you for the insightful conversation!
